headline: Nvidia has largest short position by dollar value as risk exposure declines - S3
summary: Investing.com - NVIDIA (NASDAQ:NVDA) has become the largest short position by notional dollar value at $34.3 billion, according to research released Wednesday by S3 Partners, a technology-focused analytics firm, although by percentage of float, the short interest has declined in the AI powerhouse. Claiming the top spot in notional short is mainly related to Nvidia’s surging market capitalization, the report highlights.

raw.headline: Nvidia has largest short position by dollar value as risk exposure declines - S3
raw.summary: Investing.com - NVIDIA (NASDAQ:NVDA) has become the largest short position by notional dollar value at $34.3 billion, according to research released Wednesday by S3 Partners, a technology-focused analytics firm, although by percentage of float, the short interest has declined in the AI powerhouse. Claiming the top spot in notional short is mainly related to Nvidia’s surging market capitalization, the report highlights.

headline: Apple and Citi CEOs Join Trump and King Charles at State Dinner
summary: “In striving for a better world, we also have a precious opportunity to safeguard and restore the wonders and beauty of nature for the generations who follow us,” Charles continued.  Trump nodded along as Charles spoke, but the comments — hitting on two areas where he has broken with other allies — were particularly notable given how the state dinner was designed to curry favor with the US president and the king’s traditional restraint from engaging in political issues.

headline: Walmart Stock Heads for a Record High. The Retailer Could Become a Leader in ‘Agentic’ AI.
summary: Walmart  may not be the first company that comes to mind when you hear the term artificial intelligence.  Analysts at BofA Securities believe  Walmart  is set to become “a leader in agentic AI.”  Analysts with the firm noted that Walmart’s flagship AI agent, Sparky, “is testing well and will soon start taking ‘agentic’ action” as opposed to just answering questions.

headline: Trump's UK visit: US Big Tech to invest billions in UK's AI
summary: President Trump is visiting the UK to meet with Prime Minister Keir Starmer on Thursday, accompanied by several Big Tech CEOs. This comes as names like Microsoft (MSFT), Google (GOOG, GOOGL), Nvidia (NVDA), Salesforce (CRM), OpenAI (OPAI.PVT), and GSK (GSK) pledged $42.3 billion worth of artificial intelligence (AI) infrastructure investments in the UK as part of the "Tech Prosperity Deal." Yahoo Finance anchor Ramzan Karmali joins Morning Brief with Julie Hyman to discuss the details. To watch more expert insights and analysis on the latest market action, check out more Morning Brief.

Yahoo Finance anchor Ramzan Karmali joins Morning Brief with Julie Hyman to discuss the details. To watch more expert insights and analysis on the latest market action, check out more Morning Brief.

headline: Rimo3 and Microsoft Launch Official Intune Migration Program to Accelerate SCCM-to-Intune Transition
summary: Rimo3, the leader in intelligent Windows workspace management, today announced the official Intune Migration Program with Microsoft. The program gives enterprises a faster, lower-risk path to move applications and devices from Microsoft Configuration Manager (SCCM) to Microsoft Intune, combining Rimo3's intelligent automation with guided onboarding so organizations can validate and migrate every application in days rather than weeks or months.

raw.headline: Rimo3 and Microsoft Launch Official Intune Migration Program to Accelerate SCCM-to-Intune Transition
raw.summary: Rimo3, the leader in intelligent Windows workspace management, today announced the official Intune Migration Program with Microsoft. The program gives enterprises a faster, lower-risk path to move applications and devices from Microsoft Configuration Manager (SCCM) to Microsoft Intune, combining Rimo3's intelligent automation with guided onboarding so organizations can validate and migrate every application in days rather than weeks or months.

headline: AI Weekly: OpenAI makes a deal, Oracle makes waves
summary: STORY: From OpenAI getting one step closer to making money, to how Oracle made Wall Street take notice, this is AI Weekly.:: AI Weekly:: MicrosoftMicrosoft and OpenAI have struck a deal to restructure their relationship.Though the details aren’t set in stone, that should clear the way for the ChatGPT maker to become a for-profit firm.OpenAI wants more freedom to work with other firms besides Microsoft, which has been its main backer.:: MicrosoftBut the Windows maker wants to make sure it keeps access to the startup’s AI tech.Nvidia’s latest chips for the Chinese market seem to be getting a lukewarm response.Reuters sources say some major tech firms there have opted not to place orders.They say the new chip is seen as expensive for what it does.And they say performance lags older models that the U.S. has banned for sale in China, but which are readily available through grey market channels.:: OracleOracle has gone from AI laggard to potential champion.Shares in the firm surged after it gave a bullish outlook for sales related to the new tech, while the Wall Street Journal says it has a $300 billion deal just with OpenAI.GLOBALT Investments partner Keith Buchanan says the numbers made Wall Street take notice:"The sheer magnitude of just how quickly they've been able to get up the curve and also show it through commitments on the other side is what the big surprise was.” Donald Trump hit London for a state visit, with the two sides agreeing an AI-focused tech deal to mark the event.That will see top US firms invest billions in the country to help drive the new tech.Among other projects, Microsoft said it would spend around $30 billion to expand AI and cloud infrastructure in the UK, while also helping to build the country’s biggest AI supercomputer.And AI has wildlife experts puzzled.Researchers used the tech to estimate the number of wildebeest in Africa’s so-called Great Migration.:: Maxar Technologies / Tiejun WangThe bots looked at satellite images, and counted 600,000 of the animals, or less than half the number usually cited.:: Maxar Technologies / Tiejun WangNow the question is whether wildebeest numbers are really falling, or if one of the two estimates is way out.

raw.headline: AI Weekly: OpenAI makes a deal, Oracle makes waves
raw.summary: STORY: From OpenAI getting one step closer to making money, to how Oracle made Wall Street take notice, this is AI Weekly.:: AI Weekly:: MicrosoftMicrosoft and OpenAI have struck a deal to restructure their relationship.Though the details aren’t set in stone, that should clear the way for the ChatGPT maker to become a for-profit firm.OpenAI wants more freedom to work with other firms besides Microsoft, which has been its main backer.:: MicrosoftBut the Windows maker wants to make sure it keeps access to the startup’s AI tech.Nvidia’s latest chips for the Chinese market seem to be getting a lukewarm response.Reuters sources say some major tech firms there have opted not to place orders.They say the new chip is seen as expensive for what it does.And they say performance lags older models that the U.S. has banned for sale in China, but which are readily available through grey market channels.:: OracleOracle has gone from AI laggard to potential champion.Shares in the firm surged after it gave a bullish outlook for sales related to the new tech, while the Wall Street Journal says it has a $300 billion deal just with OpenAI.GLOBALT Investments partner Keith Buchanan says the numbers made Wall Street take notice:"The sheer magnitude of just how quickly they've been able to get up the curve and also show it through commitments on the other side is what the big surprise was.” Donald Trump hit London for a state visit, with the two sides agreeing an AI-focused tech deal to mark the event.That will see top US firms invest billions in the country to help drive the new tech.Among other projects, Microsoft said it would spend around $30 billion to expand AI and cloud infrastructure in the UK, while also helping to build the country’s biggest AI supercomputer.And AI has wildlife experts puzzled.Researchers used the tech to estimate the number of wildebeest in Africa’s so-called Great Migration.:: Maxar Technologies / Tiejun WangThe bots looked at satellite images, and counted 600,000 of the animals, or less than half the number usually cited.:: Maxar Technologies / Tiejun WangNow the question is whether wildebeest numbers are really falling, or if one of the two estimates is way out.

headline: How Rising Sales and Lower Profits at STEF (ENXTPA:STF) Has Changed Its Investment Story
summary: STEF SA reported results for the first half of 2025, with sales reaching €2.47 billion, up from €2.33 billion a year prior, but net income falling sharply to €15.83 million from €67.97 million. This combination of higher sales and sharply lower profitability signals potential cost pressures or margin challenges affecting STEF's overall performance. We'll examine how the pressure on profitability revealed in this earnings report shapes STEF's broader investment narrative moving forward. The...

headline: These Stocks Are Moving the Most Today: Nvidia, Workday, Tesla, FedEx, General Mills, and More
summary: Stock futures were mixed Wednesday with Wall Street widely expecting the Federal Reserve to reduce a key interest rate by a quarter-point later in the trading session.  Nvidia  fell 1.3% after report from the Financial Times said China’s internet regulator had banned the country’s biggest tech companies from buying its artificial-intelligence chips.  The Cyberspace Administration of China told TikTok parent ByteDance and e-commerce giant  Alibaba  among others, to end testing and orders of Nvidia’s tailored-made products for China, the Financial Times reported, citing people familiar with the matter.

The Cyberspace Administration of China told TikTok parent ByteDance and e-commerce giant  Alibaba  among others, to end testing and orders of Nvidia’s tailored-made products for China, the Financial Times reported, citing people familiar with the matter.

headline: Oracle Sparks Bubble Talk With Stock Price in Dot-Com Territory
summary: Shares of the database software company have soared 84% this year, the seventh-best performance in the S&P 500 Index, as scorching demand for AI computing turbocharges its revenue growth.  Oracle also has been linked to the Trump administration’s negotiations to keep TikTok operating in the US.  The company has served as TikTok’s primary cloud infrastructure provider for years.

Oracle also has been linked to the Trump administration’s negotiations to keep TikTok operating in the US.  The company has served as TikTok’s primary cloud infrastructure provider for years.

headline: UK and US sign $42 bln tech pact to mark Trump's state visit
summary: STORY: Donald Trump arrived in the UK late Tuesday (September 16) for an unprecedented second state visit to the country.The trip will see both pomp and protests, but the two countries also hope it will mark the start of a new era in investment.To mark the event, they’ve agreed a “Tech Prosperity Deal” with an estimated value of $42 billion.Among the major investments promised…Microsoft says it will spend around $30 billion expanding cloud and AI infrastructure in the UK.It will also help build the country’s biggest AI supercomputer in north-east London.Google promised almost $7 billion in spending on a new data center and AI research.And Nvidia said it would deploy 120,000 advanced chips across the country.It could all be a timely boost for embattled UK Prime Minister Keir Starmer, who is under pressure to revive growth.He wants to pitch Britain as a destination for further investment, touting it as offering the kind of light-touch regulation favored by the US.The UK government says the new pact will include efforts to use AI in healthcare, expand quantum computing capabilities and streamline civil nuclear projects.Trump’s visit is unlikely to be all plain sailing, however, with the U.S. president a divisive figure in the UK.In a possible taste of things to come, protesters projected images of him with the late sex offender Jeffrey Epstein onto the walls of Windsor Castle.Starmer will be hoping there are no more such stunts when his guest arrives at the castle on Wednesday (September 17) to be feted with a day of royal pageantry.

raw.headline: UK and US sign $42 bln tech pact to mark Trump's state visit
raw.summary: STORY: Donald Trump arrived in the UK late Tuesday (September 16) for an unprecedented second state visit to the country.The trip will see both pomp and protests, but the two countries also hope it will mark the start of a new era in investment.To mark the event, they’ve agreed a “Tech Prosperity Deal” with an estimated value of $42 billion.Among the major investments promised…Microsoft says it will spend around $30 billion expanding cloud and AI infrastructure in the UK.It will also help build the country’s biggest AI supercomputer in north-east London.Google promised almost $7 billion in spending on a new data center and AI research.And Nvidia said it would deploy 120,000 advanced chips across the country.It could all be a timely boost for embattled UK Prime Minister Keir Starmer, who is under pressure to revive growth.He wants to pitch Britain as a destination for further investment, touting it as offering the kind of light-touch regulation favored by the US.The UK government says the new pact will include efforts to use AI in healthcare, expand quantum computing capabilities and streamline civil nuclear projects.Trump’s visit is unlikely to be all plain sailing, however, with the U.S. president a divisive figure in the UK.In a possible taste of things to come, protesters projected images of him with the late sex offender Jeffrey Epstein onto the walls of Windsor Castle.Starmer will be hoping there are no more such stunts when his guest arrives at the castle on Wednesday (September 17) to be feted with a day of royal pageantry.
